content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata>  <idinfo>   <citation>    <citeinfo>     <origin>           Pacific Islands Benthic Habitat Mapping Center (PIBHMC), Coral Reef Ecosystem Division (CRED), Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center (PIFSC), National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)         </origin>     <pubdate>           20100824         </pubdate>     <title>           Bathymetric Position Index (BPI) Structures 5 m grid derived from gridded bathymetry of Ni'ihau Island, Hawaii, USA.         </title>     <geoform>           raster digital data         </geoform>     <onlink>           http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/pibhmc         </onlink>     <onlink>           http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/pibhmc/pibhmc_mhi_nii_geomorph.htm         </onlink>    </citeinfo>   </citation>   <descript>    <abstract>         BPI Structures are derived from two scales of a focal mean analysis on bathymetry and slope. The grid is based on gridded (5 m cell size) multibeam bathymetry, collected aboard NOAA ship Hi'ialakai and R/V AHI.  BPI Structures was created using the Benthic Terrain Modeler (http://www.csc.noaa.gov/products/btm/). Cell values represent one of 13 classes in an index of seafloor terrains. This data set is for Ni'ihau Island, Hawaii, USA.       </abstract>    <purpose>         The data were derived in support of Coral Reef Conservation Program goals. Goal 1 is to map all U.S. Coral Reef Ecosystems. This data set specifically addresses Objective 1 and 4: to develop high-resolution benthic maps and to characterize priority deep water reefs and associated habitats.  This derivative of bathymetry provides a GIS layer that may be used for benthic and essential fish habitat characterization, and for the study of geologic features. By combining the dataset with bathymetry, backscatter, other derivatives, and in situ data, they collectively compose benthic habitat maps which are designed to be used to understand and predict moderate depth (~20m to ~150m) benthic habitats for different organisms that inhabit coral reef ecosystems.       </purpose>    <supplinf>         Gridded bathymetry data were collected aboard the NOAA ship Hi'ialakai a 218'research ship and R/V AHI (Acoustic Habitat Investigator), a 25' survey launch owned and operated by the NOAA Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center in Honolulu, HI.  The metadata for the bathymetry is documented in the product metadata, Nii_5m.asc. References: Lundblad et al., 2006, A benthic terrain classification scheme for American Samoa, Marine Geodesy, 29(2):89 - 111. http://www.csc.noaa.gov/products/btm/       </supplinf>   </descript> </accconst>   <useconst>       These data are not to be used for navigation purposes. Please acknowledge the NOAA Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center (PIFSC) Coral Reef Ecosystem Division (CRED) and the Pacific Islands Benthic Habitat Mapping Center, and the Joint Institute for Marine and Atmospheric Research (JIMAR) and School of Ocean and Earth Science and Technology (SOEST), University of Hawaii as the sources of this information.     </useconst>   <browse>    <browsen>         http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/pibhmc/MHI_images/Nii_5m_BPIStructures_445.jpg       </browsen>    <browsed>         Gridded Bathymetry Derivative       </browsed>    <browset>         JPEG       </browset>   </browse>   <datacred>       NOAA PIFSC CRED PIBHMC, JIMAR, and SOEST     </datacred>   <secinfo>    <secsys>         Not applicable       </secsys>    <secclass>         Unclassified       </secclass>    <sechandl>         Not applicable       </sechandl>   </secinfo>   <native>       ArcGIS ASCII file, derived from bathymetry and slope in ArcGIS 9.3 (Spatial Analyst and Benthic Terrain Modeler)     </native>  </idinfo>  <dataqual>   <attracc>    <attraccr>         Data are collected for resource management and research purposes and are tested for internal consistency; however, no effort is made to compare these data to external references or to other published data.       </attraccr>   </attracc>   <logic>       These data are believed to be logically consistent though no tests were performed     </logic>   <complete>       Complete     </complete>   <posacc>    <horizpa>     <horizpar>           Horizontal positioning system: GPS C/A Horizontal position accuracy: 25 meters         </horizpar>    </horizpa>    <vertacc>     <vertaccr>           Range resolution of sonar: varies with depth Raw sounding resolution: varies with depth Vertical accuracy of gridded product ~ 1% of water depth         </vertaccr>    </vertacc>   </posacc>   <lineage>    <procstep>     <procdesc>           Bathymetric Position Index Structures were derived from the gridded multibeam bathymetry (nii_5m) using the Benthic Terrain Modeler (BTM). The BTM (written for ArcGIS 8.x or 9.x) may be downloaded from http://dusk2.geo.orst.edu/djl/samoa/tools.html. BPI Structures are derived from two scales of a focal mean analysis on bathymetry and slope. After testing 10 experimental combinations, two scales (50 and 250) best identified fine scale structures for Ni'ihau Island while minimizing noise and optimizing possible reef structures (also after Lundblad et al. 2006; see Supplemental_Information).  Three ranges of slope define flat, slope, and near vertical: x < 5; 5 < x < 70;  x > 70. There may be edge effects on both landward and seaward sides.         </procdesc>     <procdate>           20100715         </procdate>    </procstep>   </lineage>  </dataqual>  <spdoinfo>   <direct>
